Hello,

I hope you are well.
We have received an update regarding your remaining queries on this topic, please see below:

Root Cause:

The discrepancy arose due to an inconsistency between the global rights set on the Unify console and the device-level settings. While the global rights were correctly configured to "Deny Access," the settings on the affected node permitted access, which caused the unintended behavior.

Resolution:

Our team has realigned the node settings with the Unify console to ensure consistent application of the Bluetooth device blocking policies. We have also advised our technical team to enhance monitoring processes to detect and prevent similar inconsistencies in the future.

To ensure sustained functionality, we recommend the following:

Periodic Validation: Regularly review and validate global rights settings and ensure they are effectively propagated across all nodes and devices.

Updated Procedures: In case of any future discrepancies, trying a reset by toggling the settings off and on, or removing and re-adding specific devices that seem affected, can help in re-establishing intended configurations.

Thank you,

Hi Christian,

If I have understood the problem that has arisen correctly, a comparison of local and global settings is of little use. The problem only arose after a local setting was deleted and therefore the global setting should actually be adopted.
If a local setting is deleted, the computer is still of a custom type in the computers list, so Global will not apply unless the computer is restored to global settings. That is done by editing the settings of the computer, and "restore global settings" at the bottom of the page. The same applies to Rights.

Checking the settings on the affected node is not possible. The settings can be checked on affected computers.
Correct, as the node itself cannot be checked, but the affected computers can be checked.

It is also not possible to check the local settings on 120.000 computers as a regularly review and validate.
I understand that, but when there are affected computers, this should be checked. Since you have such a large environment, to make the check easier, you can go to the computers page and sort by the settings, then rights columns and see if there are any of Custom type. Those will not switch to global rights or settings unless restored.


A reset by toggling the settings off and on, or removing and re-adding specific devices that seem affected, is not feasible, as only a local setting was removed in this case
Not sure what you mean, but if the setting was removed on the computer directly, then it will have custom settings.

Let me know if you have follow-up questions.
